Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I have to have my first ever MRI of my breasts before having my lumpectomy.  I know you cannot have jewelry on when going through one of those machines, but I cannot get my wedding ring off.  So, and I know this is probably a silly question, but do I need to go to a jewelry store to have it cut off before going to my appointment?  Second, any other advice for someone who has never had an MRI? Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: MRI question BioAdoptMom3 mbspires

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I am thinking seriously about taking our 11 y/o DD to our appointment at the surgeon's office the end of next week when we go for my surgery consultation.  The purpose would be to make sure she hears from a professional that my outlook is good to just reassure her in general about all of this, however I don't want to take any chances on scaring her either.  She has not outwardly expressed concern except for to say yes to DH when he asked her the other day if she was worried about mommy.  She is very quiet about it.  We have only been to the surgeon twice (once was just for him to order the original biopsy) and he seems to have an excellent bedside manner.  Of course I will call to ask about doing this ahead of time, but was just wondering if anyone has done it and were you glad you did? Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone ever take an older child.... BioAdoptMom3 Laurie08

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: for you to get all the details of your cancer diagnosis?  My biopsy was done on January 7 and so far all I know for sure is that I have invasive ductal carcinoma.  How long did it take for you to find out your stage, what your tumor is most likely to be responsive to, etc.?  Does most of that not come till after the lumpectomy?  Thanks for putting up with my endless questions!  I am so new to this. Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How long did it take.... BioAdoptMom3 Shirlrae

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I don't know if anyone else has noticed this or not as I have only been diagnosed now for a week, but I have actually been able to remain for the most part, kind of positive about it all.  However tonight our 11 y/o DD forgot her notes for a science assignment and was carrying on and being stubborn about that, and there was just a lot going on, nothing earth shattering, just a lot to do.  Well tonight I am having an incredibly hard time coping with the cancer because I feel like the other issues have sent me over the top.  Its almost like I have this feeling that all I can do is deal with this and don't have the time or energy to think about any other problems.  I feel really irritable and nervous now, like I need a Xanax and this is honestly the first time I have felt that way since last week.  Typical for us? Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I can be positive until... BioAdoptMom3 julie75

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I haven't spent a lot of time on this section of the board because I just found out for sure last week that I am definitely stage 1.  I would appreciate your honest answers because I am trying to prepare myself for whatever may lie ahead, the best I can.  I was assuming (never a good idea I know) that since my stats are what they are (listed below) I would be going right from surgery to rads and probably Tamoxifen.  However I have noticed that several fellow sisters on this BC board are of my stage, and some even with a lower grade tumor, and are taking chemo.  We haven't yet seen the medical oncologist (surgeon's office is setting up an appt.) but the surgeon also stated last week that I will probably at least be offered chemo.  I do realize there are other factors at play here and I may indeed be traveling down that road in the near future. I am very curious as to why chemo was suggested for you if your stats are similar to mine.  I also want to clarify that though I will jump for joy if I do not need it, I am grateful that it is available so that we can do everything possible to prevent this beast from returning months or years later!  So please be honest with me.  Thanks in advance! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: ? for stage 1, hormone +, her2- sisters on chemo BioAdoptMom3 mdg

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I had 2 lumpectomies (one on each side) along with some lymph node removal on the cancerous side.  They told me to leave the steri-strips on for about 2 weeks.  Well, its been 8 days and both lumpectomy areas are starting to itch.  The strips over the lymph node site are starting to feel kind of sticky and uncomfortable.  I was going to call the doctor today, but I forgot.  Do you all think it might be OK to remove them either now, or maybe by the weekend?  It's getting pretty uncomfortable. Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: ? about steri-strips BioAdoptMom3 marticcrn

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I was warned this was possible by my surgeon.  I should be so happy as today we got the news that there was no lymph node involvement, but instead I am incredibly down about the fact that I didn't have clear margins and have to have surgery again next Friday, to remove more margins  !  I am sure there must be at least a few others here.  How was your recovery the second time around?  Thanks for the warm welcome you have given me here and for all of your empathy! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How many others had to have more surgery? BioAdoptMom3 cantgarden

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I am scheduled to have my lumpectomy on February 9, but based on my calculations (I am not always regular) I could be on the 2nd, 3rd or 4th day of my period.  Can they do the surgery if that is the case?  Do you think its something they need to know, or does it probably not matter?  I am also concerned for obvious reasons, just having to deal with that while having and recovering from surgery.  Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Very TMI question BioAdoptMom3 BioAdoptMom3

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I had my pre-lumpectomy MRI last Thursday and today when we met with the radiology oncologist we learned that I had another suspicous area on the other breast!  My surgery was scheduled for a week from this Wednesday (2/9) but now I am having an ultrasound this Thursday and if that doesn't prove there is nothing to be concerned about, I'll be having an MRI guided biopsy.  I guess that means the surgery will be postponed because not only will I have to wait for the biopsy, but the results are going to take another 3 to 5 business days.  Has this happened to anyone else?  What was the result?  Its so frustrating! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: They found another suspicious area! BioAdoptMom3 mdg

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: If you have a port, did you have it done with only a local, twilight sleep or general anesthesia?  If you had it to do over again would you do it the same way? Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Port with sedation or only local? BioAdoptMom3 msphil

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I was just wondering how many of you were still very tired a week after your surgery?  I had a lumpectomy on both sides with node dissection on the cancerous side (other side was a papaloma) on 2/23 and last Friday, 3/11, I had a re-excision because of unclear margins.  I have been doing some little things all week, but today I went to the gym then when I got home I insisted against his better judgment that DH start the lawn mower so I could mow.  I just needed to be doing something productive outside - so sick of sitting around having others wait on me all the time.  Well, by the time I got done and was in the shower I felt so exhausted that it was an effort to finish the shower.  I am whipped right now.  And its not as if I am not getting enough sleep.  I am a teacher who has been on spring break all week and sleeping in almost every morning.  It just seems like I should have a lot more energy 3 1/2 weeks after the initial surgery and a full week after a simple re-excision.  I am used to being on the go all the time.  Is this normal or is it me?  Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Fatigue after lumpectomy, normal? BioAdoptMom3 Janney03

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: Just wondering if anyone has joined a breast cancer support group (besides this wonderful online one)?  If you have, is it helpful for you?  I was just diagnosed 10 days ago and my surgeon gave me a list of resources and numbers.  I have having such a hard time with mood swings since my diagnosis that I am wondering if this might be what I need to help me through. Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Has anyone joined a support group yet? BioAdoptMom3 BioAdoptMom3

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I asked on another board, but only got one response and I know there are more here who are in this category.  So, if you are stage 1, hormone receptor+ and Her2-, why was chemo recommended for you, or why did you choose it?  I may be facing this recommendation in the very near future and want to be prepared to make the best decision. Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: ? for stage 1, ER,PR+ and on chemo BioAdoptMom3 sweetcorn

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: First, let me say that my DH and I totally trust my surgeon (I was diagnosed with IDC on 1/13).  He has an excellent reputation in the community as a surgeon and is one of the most compassionate doctors whom I have ever met.  We consulted with him today as my lumpectomy is scheduled for the week after next.  He estimates me to be in stage I or stage IIA.  The tumor is small, but a grade 3.  None of the other pathology is back yet.  So today during our question/answer session I made the comment that, "If no cancer is found in my lymph nodes the medical oncologist (whom we will meet after surgery) will probably not recommend chemo, right?"  His answer to me was that chemo was not a certainty, but probably would indeed be recommended for me because of my pre-menopausal status (I am 51).  Does that sound accurate to you all, the experts who have been there (I know that no one can tell me that for sure, but just want to hear your take on this)?  I mean, he is a good surgeon, but he is not a medical oncologist.  What do you think?  Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Does what my surgeon said sound accurate? BioAdoptMom3 BioAdoptMom3

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I was pleased to have found this board where there are so many others of you with similar concerns!  Sorry there are so many of us, but happy to have support out there! I am 51 and my history is that I have been called back for repeat mammograms 4 times.  This is the 3rd time a biopsy has been recommended (ultrasound guided).  What concerns me this time is that each of the times before the techs and radiologists have been pretty positive, saying things like its not likely to be cancer, but we should do this to be certain.  When I had my 2nd mammo and ultrasound on Wednesday this radiologist seemed pretty grim telling me that he didn't like what he saw, the solid mass with jagged edges and he stated he was concerned, that I should have the biopsy asap.  The ultrasound tech was pretty somber too, telling me twice she was sorry I had to face bad news right before Christmas.  On a more positive note, my gyn called me personally yesterday AM and told me to try not to worry and enjoy my Christmas, and to be aware that a great deal of these masses like mine do turn out to be benign.  My question, and I know no one can know for sure without the biopsy, but do you think it is much more likely that this is cancer because of the reactions of the tech and radiologist, or do you think it was probably just a different personality delivering the news?  This was done at the same imaging center as the others have been, but always different radiologists.  Thanks for any comments or experiences you can share, positive or negative!  I want honesty because I want to be prepared. Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Newbie, worried, comments? BioAdoptMom3 4Darla

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: Today when DH and I saw the MO he went over a little bit about my upcoming treatment plan with me (T/C).  One of the things he said was that they would load me up on anti-nausea meds at the time of treatment and that should hold me for a day or two.  Then he said I could take the prescription meds if I needed them, but to take them as soon as I noticed the first twinge of nausea.  Well, that conflicts with everything I have recently heard and read about staying ahead of the nausea by taking it around the clock for the first 3 days or so, feeling sick or not.  DH and I were discussing this tonight and he said he said he couldn't understand why I would want to take medicine if I didn't need it but of course I should do what I felt was best.  He is going by what th MO said.  Nausea to me is unbearable and I have heard once it starts from chemo it is hard to get under control.  I am going to my chemo class this coming Monday and will ask the nurse, but what do you all do as far as the meds are concerned?  Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Conflict - re: anti-nausea meds? BioAdoptMom3 208sandy

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: I am just curious as to how many of you were told by the radiologist that he or she was very concerned about your mass (I asked for his honest opinion when I went for my ultrasound guided biopsy today) and ended up not having cancer?  I know its possible because he did tell me that this still could turn out to be benign, but am wondering when that happens what the statistics are?  He did emphasize that the mass is very small and IF it is it malignant should be easily treatable.  DH and I are remaining positive because we know that the outlook for complete cure if this is not benign is excellent, but I really am curious as to how many of you were told or know someone who was told this and you or that person ended up not having cancer?  I also am aware that many of folks here are here because they did get a cancer diagnosis.  Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How many of you were told.... BioAdoptMom3 marie5890

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: Does this term mean you are positive for both estrogen and progesterone if that is what your lab report says?  My surgeon just told us the prilimary report came back as highly hormone receptor positive, but I didn't think to ask which hormone, or if it was both, etc.  I am assuming it must mean both, but am not sure.  We will see him again on Monday, but I am curious.  Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Does hormone receptor+ mean... BioAdoptMom3 BioAdoptMom3

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: First, my RO told me unexpectedly last Friday that my oncotype was back and I was going to be having chemo (it was only about 8 days after my pathology had been sent to the lab and I certainly didn't expect the RO and MO to collaborate and then have the RO tell me at my appointment).  So on Saturday I was embarrssed to ask DH, so I went to my email to see if I really had sent out an update to family and friends, so I could be sure it wasn't a dream. Then yesterday, all day long I kept thinking they mixed up my oncotype with someone else's, the RO gave me the wrong news or any number of things that may not be correct in my diagnosis.  I knew that wasn't reality, but I couldn't stop the thoughts and was setting myself up for the bottom to drop out again.  Today I am facing reality and actually made appointment for tomorrow to have my hair cut short, but boy, sometimes I just feel like this whole thing is one big dream and I going to wake up any minute and find out it's not true!   Thanks for listening! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Do you somtimes feel like you're going crazy? BioAdoptMom3 duckyb1

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: If you're still awake tonight, good luck to you tomorrow with your lumpectomy!  Prayers! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: NJMarilyn! BioAdoptMom3 NJMarilyn

Posts.Content: BioAdoptMom3 wrote: This is one of the pain/inflammation prescriptions I was given yesterday after my surgery (lumpectomy and a few nodes).  I was told it is an anti-inflamatory, similar to but stronger than Motrin.  I have been fine on it until this evening, when I started with stomach cramps and diarrhea first, then vomiting.  Of course none of this started until after 4 PM when the doctor's office was closed for the day.  Yesterday they kind of acted like I could take the pain medicine as needed (only took one of those - last night), but this one should be taken for at least five days, I am sure because of the swelling. If you have been on this and had problems with it, was it OK to stop taking it?  I don't want to cause any recovery problems, but I certainly don't want to have to deal with this either. Thanks! Nancy Nancy Dx 1/13/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone taken Ketorolac? TMI! BioAdoptMom3 Lou10
